ECE335H1.name: Introduction to Electronic Devices
ECE335H1.description: This course explores the electrical properties of semiconductor structures and devices, including metal-semiconductor contacts, pn junctions, diodes, photodetectors, LED's, bipolar junction transistors, Ebers-Moll and hybrid-pi models, field effect transistors, MOSFET, JFET/MESFET structures and models, thyristors, and semiconductor lasers.

ECE318H1.name: Fundamentals of Optics
ECE318H1.description: This course covers geometric optics including spherical surfaces, lenses, mirrors, and optical imaging systems; Polarization, including polarizers, anisotropic materials, dichroism, birefringence, and the Faraday effect; Interference, encompassing wave superposition, coherence, and various interferometer types; and Diffraction and Fourier Optics, focusing on diffraction theory, spatial filtering, and basic optical signal processing.

ECE427H1.name: Photonic Devices
ECE427H1.description: The course delves into the photonic devices and integrated systems powering modern technologies like smart glasses, AR/VR displays, and autonomous vehicles, focusing on how they interact with human visual perception. It breaks down advanced photonic systems used in optical display and sensing, examining their foundational principles.

ECE330H1.name: Quantum and Semiconductor Physics
ECE330H1.description: This course offers an insight into quantum physics, emphasizing its application in semiconductor behavior. It includes study of wave-particle duality, Schr√∂dinger's equation, quantum tunneling, and the role of electrons in crystalline semiconductors, anchoring these concepts in the context of nanotechnology, microelectronics, and optoelectronics.

ECE437H1.name: VLSI Technology
ECE437H1.description: This course offers an introductory exploration into VLSI fabrication methods, integrated circuit design, and advanced semiconductor devices. Key topics include MOS and bipolar devices, various CMOS technologies, and physical scaling limitations. It also covers CAD tools, design methodology for cutting-edge semiconductor devices and circuits, and advanced technologies like GaN HEMTs and graphene devices.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE314H1.name: Fundamentals of Electrical Energy Systems
ECE314H1.description: This course explores high-efficiency energy conversion through switched-mode power electronic circuits, focusing on the design and modeling of DC/DC and DC/AC converters. It examines transistor switches, efficiency in power electronic converters, and AC power quality, including irregular currents. The course delves into magnetic device-based energy conversion, covering topics like Faraday's law in dynamic fields, magnetic material loss characteristics, and magnetic circuit modeling, leading to an introduction to electromechanical energy conversion.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE313H1.name: Energy Systems and Distributed Generation
ECE313H1.description: Three-phase systems; steady-state transmission line model; symmetrical three-phase faults; power system stability; symmetrical components; unsymmetrical faults and fault current calculation; distribution network; equivalent steady-state model of voltage-sourced converter; distributed energy resources (DR); distributed energy storage; interface between DR and power system.

ECE320H1.name: Fields and Waves
ECE320H1.description: Voltage and current waves on a general transmission line, characteristic impedance, reflections from the load and source, transients on a transmission line, Smith's chart and impedance matching. Maxwell's equations, wave equation, constitutive relations, dispersion, boundary conditions. Plane wave propagation in lossless and lossy media, polarization, power flow and Poynting vector. Plane wave reflection and transmission at material boundaries. Waveguides; propagating and evanescent waveguide modes and cut-off frequencies.

ECE422H1.name: Radio and Microwave Wireless Systems
ECE422H1.description: Analysis and design of systems employing radio waves, covering both the underlying electromagnetics and the overall system performance aspects such as signal-to-noise ratios. Transmission/reception phenomena include: electromagnetic wave radiation and polarization; elementary and linear dipoles; directivity, gain, efficiency; integrated, phased-array and aperture antennas; beam-steering; Friis transmission formula and link budget. Propagation phenomena include: diffraction and wave propagation over obstacles; multipath propagation; atmospheric and ionospheric effects. Receiver design aspects include: radio receiver architectures, receiver figures of merit, noise in cascaded systems, noise figure, and noise temperature. System examples are: terrestrial communication systems; satellite communications; radar; radiometric receivers; software-defined radio.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE526H1.name: Power System Protection and Automation
ECE526H1.description: Presents the concepts of short-circuit fault analysis, protective relaying, and automation in power systems. The course starts by discussing the causes and types of short-circuit faults using real-world examples. The consequences of faults for different power system components are reviewed using event reports from field data. The method of symmetrical components for analyzing unbalanced three-phase systems are introduced. Analytical methods and computer-based approaches for deriving fault voltages and currents are discussed and the effect of system grounding during transient conditions, including faults, are introduced. Students also learn the concept of power system automation and its role in monitoring, protection, and control of modern power systems. Critical devices used in an automation system, such as breakers, relays, reclosers, capacitor bank controllers, and tap changer controllers are presented.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE463H1.name: Electric Drives
ECE463H1.description: Electric drives comprise electric machines (i.e., motors/generators) together with power electronic actuation to enable the control of mechanical motion. Topics include electro-mechanical mechanisms for torque production relevant to rotating machines, speed-torque diagrams, DC machine analysis, dynamics and torque/speed/position control, introduction to space vectors and their application to motion control of synchronous machines and stepper motors. Steady state and variable speed operation of the induction machine using constant flux control is also covered.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE520H1.name: Power Electronics
ECE520H1.description: The course focuses on power electronic converters utilized in applications ranging from low-power mobile devices to higher power applications such as electric vehicles, server farms, microgrids, and renewable energy systems. Concepts covered include the principles of efficient electrical energy processing (dc-dc, dc/ac, and ac/ac) through switch-mode energy conversion, converter loss analysis, large- and small-signal modeling of power electronic circuits and controller design.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

BME595H1.name: Medical Imaging
BME595H1.description: An introductory course to medical imaging and is designed as a final year course for engineers. The main clinical imaging modalities are covered: magnetic resonance imaging, ultrasound imaging, x-ray and computed tomography, nuclear medicine, and clinical optical imaging. Emphasis is placed on the underlying physical and mathematical concepts behind each modality, and applications are discussed in the context of how different modalities complement one another in the clinical setting.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE424H1.name: Microwave Circuits
ECE424H1.description: Losses in conductors and dielectrics; RF and microwave transmission lines; transients on transmission lines; matching networks; planar transmission lines (microstrip, stripline, coplanar waveguide); design with scattering parameters; 3- and 4-port RF devices (power dividers/combiners, couplers, isolators & circulators); coupled lines and devices; microwave active circuits (RF amplifiers, mixers, and receiver front ends); RF and microwave filters. The hands-on laboratories engage students in the design, simulation, fabrication, and test of practical passive and active microwave circuits using industry-standard RF/microwave simulation tools and measurement systems.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE331H1.name: Analog Electronics
ECE331H1.description: This course delves into transistor amplifiers, focusing on integrated circuit (IC) design. Key topics include differential and multistage amplifiers, IC biasing, output stage design, and the frequency response of amplifiers at different frequencies. Students will explore feedback amplifier analysis along with stability and compensation in amplifiers using negative feedback.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE334H1.name: Digital Electronics
ECE334H1.description: Focused on digital design for integrated circuits, particularly logic gate design at the transistor level. The course highlights various logic families, with a special emphasis on CMOS. Topics include device modeling, IC processing, Spice simulation, CMOS logic design, timing approximations, and key components like flipflops, decoders, and memory types such as SRAMs and DRAMs.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE412H1.name: Analog Signal Processing Circuits
ECE412H1.description: This course provides an overview of both continuous-time and discrete-time signal processing techniques. It covers the analysis and design of analog and mixed-signal circuit blocks used in electronic systems. Topics include continuous-time filters, phase noise in Phase Lock Loops, discrete-time signal analysis, and the fundamentals of digital-to-analog and analog-to-digital converters.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE430H1.name: Analog Integrated Circuits
ECE430H1.description: Reviewing MOSFET semiconductor device equations, this course covers noise in electronic devices and various single-stage amplifiers. Students will learn about CMOS op amps, their compensation, and advanced circuitry, including fully-differential op amps and common mode feedback.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE532H1.name: Digital Systems Design
ECE532H1.description: Covering advanced concepts in digital systems design, this course includes project planning, design flows, and hardware/software interfacing. It emphasizes embedded processors, software drivers, operating systems, memory interfaces, and system-level timing analysis. A significant project is implemented on an FPGA development board.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE446H1.name: Sensory Communication
ECE446H1.description: This course delves into physical and physiological acoustics, electroacoustic transducers, and acoustic measurements. It covers speech processing, recognition algorithms, and signal processing by the auditory system. The course also touches on noise control, electrical models of acoustic systems, and an introduction to vision and other sensory modalities.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE311H1.name: Introduction to Control Systems
ECE311H1.description: This course offers an initial look at dynamic systems and their management. It includes the study of differential equation models for various systems like mechanical, electrical, and electromechanical, and approaches these models through state variable form. The course explores linearization of non-linear models, transfer functions, Laplace transform applications in solving differential equations, block diagram manipulation, and time response analysis. It delves into feedback control systems, steady-state tracking, stability concepts, and frequency response, emphasizing Routh-Hurwitz stability criteria, root locus, as well as Bode and Nyquist plots.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE316H1.name: Communication Systems
ECE316H1.description: An introductory exploration into analog and digital communication systems. This course covers analog and digital signals, signal representation using Fourier transforms, bandwidth considerations, and spectral densities. It delves into analog communication methods like amplitude, frequency, and phase modulation, along with frequency division multiplexing. The digital aspects include sampling, quantization, pulse code modulation, baseband digital communication, intersymbol interference, and various modulation techniques. The course also examines the performance of analog and digital modulation schemes in noisy environments.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

BME445H1.name: Neural Bioelectricity
BME445H1.description: This course investigates the generation and transmission of bioelectricity in neural networks of the brain. It covers the basic attributes of neural systems, ion transport in cell membranes, and electrical propagation in neural cables. Additional topics include extracellular electric fields, neural networks and neuroplasticity, biological clocks, and the role of artificial neural networks in learning and memory. Laboratory experiences include biological measurements of body surface potentials and computer-based experiments on neuronal electrical activities.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

BME331H1.name: Physiological Control Systems
BME331H1.description: Introduces physiological control systems in the human body with a quantitative modeling approach. Covers the endocrine system, the cardiovascular system, and the nervous and musculoskeletal systems. Focuses on system modeling and response using linear control theory.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE302H1.name: Probability and Applications
ECE302H1.description: This course delves into the fundamentals of probability, emphasizing its application in electrical and computer engineering. Topics include events and sample spaces, discrete and continuous random variables, distribution and density functions, and common distributions like Bernoulli, Binomial, Poisson, exponential, and Gaussian. The course also explores expectation, moments, characteristic functions, correlation coefficients, functions of random variables, and random vectors. Applications are drawn from fields like communication theory, estimation, hypothesis testing, and various areas of electrical and computer engineering.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE368H1.name: Probabilistic Reasoning
ECE368H1.description: Focus on different classes of probabilistic models and deducing actionable information from data. Covers random variables, statistics, probabilistic models including vectors, temporal and graphical, hypothesis testing, marginalization, estimation, message passing. Applications in machine learning, communications, search, recommendation systems, finance, robotics, and navigation.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE410H1.name: Linear Control Systems
ECE410H1.description: This course provides an in-depth understanding of linear control systems. It covers state space analysis, matrix exponential, linearization of nonlinear systems, and structural properties like stability, controllability, and observability. Topics include pole assignment using state feedback, state estimation using observers, feedback compensator design, optimization-based control design, linear quadratic optimal control, and the algebraic Riccati equation. The practical component includes laboratory experiments focusing on computer-aided design using MATLAB and controlling a physical system such as an inverted pendulum on a cart.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE411H1.name: Adaptive Control and Reinforcement Learning
ECE411H1.description: Introduction to adaptive control and reinforcement learning for discrete-time linear systems. Topics include discrete-time models, system stability, parameter adaptation, error models in adaptive control, control and regulation techniques, dynamic programming, and machine learning methods like Q-learning and temporal difference learning.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE417H1.name: Digital Communication
ECE417H1.description: This course introduces the foundational concepts of digital communication. It covers baseband data transmission, intersymbol interference, Nyquist pulse shaping, equalization, line coding, multi-path fading, and diversity. The course also discusses binary and M-ary modulation schemes, synchronization, signal space concepts, optimum receivers, coherent and noncoherent detectors, information theory, source encoding, and error control coding including block and convolutional codes.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE421H1.name: Introduction to Machine Learning
ECE421H1.description: This course serves as an introduction to the fundamental theory, algorithms, and computational toolboxes of machine learning. It offers a balanced approach to both practical and theoretical aspects, with hands-on software experience. Covered topics include linear models for classification and regression, neural networks, support vector machines, principal component analysis, k-means clustering, and Gaussian mixture models. Theoretical discussions will address generalization error bounds, bias-variance tradeoffs, and the Vapnik-Chervonenkis (VC) dimension. Techniques to control overfitting, including regularization and validation, are also included.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE431H1.name: Digital Signal Processing
ECE431H1.description: This course provides an introduction to digital filtering and its applications. It covers real-world signal processing, sampling, quantization of signals, discrete Fourier transform and its properties, fast Fourier transform, Fourier analysis of signals, structures for discrete-time systems, design and realization of digital filters (finite and infinite impulse response filters), and DSP applications in communications, multimedia, video coding, human-computer interaction, and medicine.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE462H1.name: Multimedia Systems
ECE462H1.description: The course delves into the engineering aspects of multimedia systems, with a focus on theory, design, performance, complexity analysis, optimization, and applications of multimedia technologies. Topics include the characterization and compression of sound, audio, images, and video; source entropy and hybrid coding; transform coding; wavelet-based coding; motion estimation; JPEG and digital video coding; MPEG-1/2 coding; content-based processing; and MPEG-7. It provides insights into the multifaceted nature of multimedia engineering.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE441H1.name: Interfacing & Modulating the Nervous System
ECE441H1.description: This course provides an extensive overview of neuromodulation's fundamental principles and clinical applications. It covers the human nervous system and neural oscillations, electrical-neural interfaces, neural recording and stimulation fundamentals, signal processing, and instrumentation. Clinical applications of neuromodulation technologies like Electroencephalography (EEG), Deep brain stimulation (DBS), Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), and Functional electrical stimulation (FES) are discussed. Recommended preparation includes BME445H1.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE464H1.name: Wireless Communication
ECE464H1.description: This course introduces the principles of wireless communication, including radio medium and system examples. It discusses link budget aspects, propagation loss, antenna gains, and propagation phenomena such as multi-path propagation and fading. The course examines various modulation schemes, speech coding, error correction coding, and the physical layer of cellular systems like AMPS, IS-54, and GSM. It also covers the cellular concept, frequency reuse, channel allocation, hand-offs, power control, traffic management, spread spectrum modulation, and CDMA networks.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE469H1.name: Optical Communications and Networks
ECE469H1.description: This course introduces students to the principles of optical communication systems and networks at both the system and functional levels. It covers applications ranging from telecommunication networks to computing networks, with topics on basic principles of optical transmission, components used for light transmission, optical network design, routing, wavelength assignment, network management, and survivability. The course offers insights into various types of networks, including short to long-haul telecommunications and optical backplanes.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE470H1.name: Robot Modeling and Control
ECE470H1.description: The course provides an in-depth understanding of robotic manipulators, covering areas such as kinematic modeling, forward and inverse kinematics, velocity kinematics, path planning, trajectory planning, dynamic modeling, Euler-Langrange equations, inverse dynamics, and control methodologies. It explores joint control, computed torque control, passivity-based control, and feedback linearization, with practical applications in the field of robotics.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE537H1.name: Random Processes
ECE537H1.description: This course delves into the principles and properties of random processes, with applications in communications, control systems, and computer science. Topics include random vectors, convergence, Poisson and Gaussian processes, stationarity, ergodicity, power spectrum, linear systems with stochastic input, and Markov chains. It also explores concepts like recurrence, absorption, limiting and steady-state distributions, time reversibility, balance equations, and their relevance in various engineering domains.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE516H1.name: Intelligent Image Processing
ECE516H1.description: This course provides an in-depth understanding of intelligent image processing, focusing on personal cybernetics applications such as wearable computing, augmented reality, and mediated reality. It covers fundamental aspects and new inventions in human-computer interaction, including mediated reality, personal safety devices, lifelong personal video capture, the Eye Tap principle, collinearity criterion, comparametric equations, photoquantigraphic imaging, lightvector spaces, anti-homomorphic imaging, application of personal imaging to the visual arts, and algebraic projective geometry.
tags: Control Systems / Communications / Digital Signal Production

ECE361H1.name: Computer Networks I
ECE361H1.description: This course introduces layered network architectures with an emphasis on the TCP/IP protocol suite. It includes an introduction to sockets and application layer protocols. The curriculum covers Peer-to-Peer Protocols such as ARQ and TCP reliable stream service, flow control, Data Link Controls like Framing, PPP, HDLC, Medium access control and LANs including Aloha, Ethernet, Wireless LANs, Bridges, Packet Switching, Datagram and virtual circuit switching, Shortest path algorithms, Distance vector and link state algorithms. Co-requisite: ECE302H1.
tags: Digital / Analog and Integrated Circuit Design

ECE342H1.name: Computer Hardware
ECE342H1.description: This course focuses on the design of digital hardware components and embedded systems. It covers finite state machines, algorithmic state machine representation, timing analysis for single and multi-clock designs, and arithmetic circuits like binary operations and IEEE 754 floating point representation. The course also delves into embedded system hardware architecture, on-chip buses, particularly the AMBA/AXI standard, processor design, pipelining, memory types, interfacing, direct memory access, and off-chip peripherals and communication protocols.

ECE461H1.name: Internetworking
ECE461H1.description: This course delves into the essentials of protocols for packet switching networks, focusing particularly on Internet-type networks. Topics include the Internetworking concept and architectural model, data link layer (Ethernet and PPP), Internet addresses, address resolution protocol, Internet protocol for connectionless datagram delivery, routing IP datagrams, Internet control message protocol, subnet and supernet address extensions, ping and traceroute programs, user datagram protocol, reliable stream transport service (TCP), socket interface, routing (GGP, EGP, IP, OSPF, HELLO), Internet multicasting, domain name system, applications such as HTTP, electronic mail, SNMP, Internet security, firewall design, Ipv6, RSVP, flows, and ISIP.

ECE552H1.name: Computer Architecture
ECE552H1.description: This course emphasizes performance analysis and metrics in computer architecture, exploring cost considerations and instruction set architectures. It delves into instruction-level parallelism through pipelining, superscalar architectures, dynamic scheduling, and VLIW processors. The course covers data-level parallelism in vector processors and GPUs, and thread-level parallelism in multiprocessors, multi-core systems, and simultaneous multi-threading. Memory hierarchies, including caches and virtual memory support, are also examined. Students will gain practical experience with simulation tools and methods.

ECE568H1.name: Computer Security
ECE568H1.description: As computing systems increasingly integrate into society, their security becomes paramount. This course covers the principles of computer systems security, emphasizing how attackers operate. Students learn to identify security vulnerabilities and exploit them, followed by techniques to build secure systems and defend against attacks. The course introduces industry standards for security audits to establish security levels and basic cryptographic techniques, as well as hardware used in cryptographic operations in devices like ATMs and web servers.

ECE466H1.name: Computer Networks II
ECE466H1.description: This course delves into advanced aspects of computer networking, focusing on traffic modeling, network calculus, and traffic classification. It includes the study of traffic regulation techniques such as shaping, filtering, policing, and leaky bucket. Students will explore queueing systems, scheduling, and quality of service concepts like Diffserv and IntServ/RSVP. The course also covers multi-protocol label switching, call admission control, congestion control, switching, pricing, and optical networks, providing a comprehensive overview of modern network technologies and techniques.

ECE344H1.name: Operating Systems
ECE344H1.description: The course focuses on the structure and functionalities of operating systems. Key topics include concurrency, synchronization mechanisms, deadlock resolution, CPU scheduling strategies, memory management techniques, and file systems. A significant component of the course involves hands-on laboratory exercises, where students will partake in the implementation of various aspects of an operating system.

ECE345H1.name: Algorithms & Data Structures
ECE345H1.description: This course covers the design and analysis of essential algorithms and data structures in engineering. It reviews foundational material such as recurrences, asymptotics, trees, and graphs. The curriculum includes sorting algorithms, search trees, balanced search trees, amortized analysis, hash functions, dynamic programming, greedy algorithms, basic graph algorithms, minimum spanning trees, shortest paths, and an introduction to NP completeness. The course also explores new trends in algorithms and data structures.

APS360H1.name: Applied Fundamentals of Deep Learning
APS360H1.description: This course provides a foundational introduction to the rapidly evolving field of deep learning. It covers topics such as neural networks, autoencoders/decoders, recurrent neural networks, natural language processing, and generative adversarial networks. Special attention is given to fairness and ethics issues surrounding machine learning. The course adopts an applied approach, allowing students hands-on exposure to the techniques using state-of-the-art machine learning software frameworks.

CSC317H1.name: Computer Graphics
CSC317H1.description: This course introduces the identification and characterization of objects in computer graphics, as well as the operations and algorithms to manipulate them. It covers topics such as display devices, data structures, graphical input, object modeling, transformations, and illumination models. The course also explores primary and secondary light effects, graphics packages, and systems. Students will engage in practical implementations of graphical algorithms or entire graphics systems.

CSC343H1.name: Introduction to Databases
CSC343H1.description: This course offers an introduction to database management systems, focusing on the relational data model and the query language SQL. It addresses application programming with SQL, integrity constraints, normal forms, and database design. The course also covers elements of database system technology, including query processing and transaction management. Students will gain practical skills in designing and managing databases for various applications.

ECE419H1.name: Distributed Systems
ECE419H1.description: This course addresses the design issues in distributed systems, including heterogeneity, security, transparency, concurrency, and fault-tolerance. It covers networking principles, request-reply protocols, remote procedure calls, distributed objects, middleware architectures like CORBA, security and authentication protocols, distributed file systems, name services, global states in distributed systems, coordination and agreement, transactions and concurrency control, distributed transactions, replication, and an overview of contemporary distributed systems technologies.

ECE448H1.name: Biocomputation
ECE448H1.description: This course introduces the convergence of biological and computer sciences, driven by the need to synthesize knowledge from vast amounts of biological data. Topics include molecular and structural biology, sequence-based algorithms (pairwise and multiple sequence alignment, statistical models), structure-based algorithms (energy models, homology modeling, threading), and systems biology algorithms (hierarchical and neural network clustering). The course aims to provide insights into the computational and statistical approaches used to model and address challenges in molecular biology.

ECE326H1.name: Programming Languages
ECE326H1.description: The course explores programming styles and paradigms, including object-oriented, scripting, functional, and logic-based approaches. It introduces languages supporting these styles, such as Python, Lisp or Scheme, and Prolog. Students will examine different programming languages, understanding their unique characteristics, applications, and how they influence software development.

ECE444H1.name: Software Engineering
ECE444H1.description: This course delves into the collaborative software development process, emphasizing software requirements elicitation, specifications, and design techniques. It explores the challenges of developing large software systems, covering aspects such as software testing, quality assurance, documentation, and maintenance. The course also addresses open-source software and web application design, providing students with a holistic understanding of software engineering practices.

ECE454H1.name: Computer Systems Programming
ECE454H1.description: This course teaches fundamental techniques for programming computer systems, focusing on performance optimization. Topics include finite precision number representations, low-level manipulation of bits and bytes, machine-level program operation, memory allocation and management, and the use of memory hierarchy for performance enhancement. Advanced topics in programming techniques are also covered, providing hands-on experience and deeper understanding of high-performance and efficient system programming.

ECE467H1.name: Compilers and Interpreters
ECE467H1.description: This course delves into the organization of compilers, including compiler writing tools and the use of regular expressions, finite automata, and context-free grammars. It covers scanning and parsing, runtime organization, semantic analysis, implementing the runtime model, storage allocation, and code generation. Students will gain a comprehensive understanding of how compilers and interpreters are designed and built, providing them with essential knowledge in computer science.

BME440H1.name: Biomedical Engineering Technology and Investigation
BME440H1.description: This course introduces fundamental biomedical research technologies with a focus on cellular and molecular methodologies. Topics include DNA and protein analysis and isolation, microscopy, cell culture, and cellular assays. The course combines theoretical concepts with practical experience through lectures and wet labs. Applications in biotechnology and medicine will be outlined and discussed, providing students with hands-on insights into the field of biomedical engineering technology.

BME455H1.name: Cellular and Molecular Bioengineering II
BME455H1.description: This course utilizes engineering and biophysical tools to deepen understanding of animal cell behavior from molecular to tissue levels. Quantitative methods are applied to model the biology of cell growth, division, and differentiation leading to tissue formation. Core topics include receptor-ligand interactions, cell adhesion and migration, signal transduction, and cell growth and differentiation, with real-world applications in cellular and tissue engineering highlighted through literature examples.

CHE353H1.name: Engineering Biology
CHE353H1.description: Using a quantitative, problem-solving approach, this course introduces basic concepts in cell biology and physiology. It employs various engineering modeling tools to investigate cell growth and metabolism, transport across cell membranes, protein structure, homeostasis, nerve conduction, and mechanical forces in biology. The course is designed for students interested in the interdisciplinary application of engineering principles to biological systems.

CIV220H1.name: Urban Engineering Ecology
CIV220H1.description: This course introduces basic concepts of ecology within the context of urban environments. It focuses on the response of organisms, populations, dynamic predator-prey and competition processes, and ecosystems to human activities. The course also covers thermodynamic basis for food chains, energy flow, biodiversity and ecosystem stability, biogeochemical cycles, habitat fragmentation, bioaccumulation, industrial ecology, life cycle assessment principles, urban metabolism, and material flow analysis of cities. Emphasis is on the environment/engineering interface and minimizing environmental impacts.

CIV300H1.name: Terrestrial Energy Systems
CIV300H1.description: This course provides a comprehensive understanding of various earth systems for energy transformation, storage, and transport. Topics include geological, hydrological, biological, cosmological, and oceanographic energy systems, solar energy variation and redistribution, atmospheric and ocean current roles in energy redistribution, polar regions, hydrological systems, tectonic systems' influence, and energy storage in physical and biological systems, including fossil fuel accumulation.

ECE367H1.name: Matrix Algebra and Optimization
ECE367H1.description: This course offers a foundation in optimization methods and matrix algebra. It starts with linear algebra fundamentals and their geometric interpretation, including matrices, linear operators, and matrix decompositions like eigen-, spectral-, and singular vector decompositions. The course then moves to optimization, encompassing unconstrained and constrained, linear and non-linear, as well as convex and non-convex optimization; local and global optimality conditions; and basic optimization problem classes. Applications in machine learning, signal processing, and engineering illustrate the techniques developed.

ESC384H1.name: Partial Differential Equations
ESC384H1.description: Introduces analytical techniques for partial differential equations (PDEs). Concepts include Fourier series, Sturm-Liouville theory, Green's functions, characteristics, and Laplace transform method. Applications are in model PDEs in continuum mechanics: diffusion, transport, heat, and wave equations.

CHE354H1.name: Cellular and Molecular Biology
CHE354H1.description: This course covers principles of molecular and cellular biology in prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells, including metabolism, enzymology, cell structures, and growth. Genetic analysis, immunohistochemistry, cloning, recombinant DNA, and biotechnology are also discussed.

PHY358H1.name: Atoms, Molecules and Solids
PHY358H1.description: This course explores quantum theory as applied to atoms, molecules, and solids. Topics include variational principle, perturbation theory, hydrogen and helium atoms, exchange and correlation energies, multi-electron atoms, simple molecules, bonding and antibonding orbitals, rotation and vibration of molecules, crystal binding, electron in a periodic potential, reciprocal lattice, Bloch's theorem, nearly-free electron model, Kronig-Penney model, energy bands, metals, semiconductors, and insulators, and Fermi surfaces.

PHY365H1.name: Quantum Information
PHY365H1.description: An introductory course to quantum computing and quantum information topics. The course covers quantum states of multi-particle systems, entanglement, Bell inequalities and teleportation, quantum key distribution, quantum computing algorithms, and quantum information processing technologies. Applications in metrology and illumination are also discussed.

ECE472H1.name: Engineering Economic Analysis & Entrepreneurship
ECE472H1.description: This course examines the economic evaluation and justification of engineering projects and investment proposals. It covers cost concepts, financial and cost accounting, depreciation, the time value of money and compound interest, inflation, capital budgeting, equity, bond and loan financing, income tax and after-tax cash flow in engineering project proposals, measures of economic merit in the public sector, sensitivity and risk analysis. The course also delves into applications such as evaluations of competing engineering project alternatives, replacement analysis, economic life of assets, lease versus buy decisions, break-even and sensitivity analysis. Additionally, entrepreneurship and the Canadian business environment are discussed.

ECE496Y1.name: Design Project
ECE496Y1.description: A capstone design project course spanning a full year, offering students the chance to apply their technical knowledge and communication skills. Working in teams under faculty supervision, students develop a design project from concept to a working prototype. The course begins with a project proposal, followed by requirements specification, and a design review meeting. Lectures in the first session focus on design and technical communication. In the second session, students present their work through various formats, including oral and poster presentations, a final demonstration at the Design Fair, individual progress reports, and a group final report. Evaluations are conducted by both the supervisor and course administrators.

CSC384H1.name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
CSC384H1.description: This course introduces the core elements of computational intelligence, covering theories and algorithms. Topics include search, logical representations and reasoning, classical automated planning, uncertainty representation and reasoning, learning, and decision making under uncertainty. The course offers practical experience in both theory and programming of the core topics, enhancing understanding of computational intelligence's fundamental aspects.

JRE300H1.name: Fundamentals of Accounting and Finance
JRE300H1.description: This course provides an overview of essential accounting and corporate finance concepts. It starts with the basics of accounting, teaching students the foundational language and concepts of financial reporting. The course emphasizes the interpretation and analysis of key financial statements, including those detailing financial position, comprehensive income, equity changes, and cash flows. Additionally, it delves into significant management accounting principles and various costing methods for decision-making. The second half of the course focuses on corporate finance, covering financial forecasting, investment valuation, risk management strategies, capital cost determination, and cash flow management. It concludes with an examination of project valuation in corporate mergers.

JRE410H1.name: Markets and Competitive Strategy
JRE410H1.description: This course introduces essential concepts, frameworks, and methodologies for managers in technology-based companies, focusing on entrepreneurial business strategies. The first part explores the business's external, internal, and dynamic environments and elements of competitive positioning. The second part deals with designing and delivering customer value, including strategic decisions about segmentation, targeting, positioning, and tactical choices concerning product launches, marketing, distribution, and pricing. The final part builds on these concepts, addressing innovation and industry dynamics challenges, such as industry life cycles, disruptive technologies, product renewal, and the R&D-commercialization relationship.

JRE420H1.name: People Management and Organizational Behaviour
JRE420H1.description: This course covers three interconnected topics within organizational behavior and human resources: individual behavior, group behavior, and leadership. It provides theoretical and practical insights on working, leading, and thriving in organizations. Topics include personality theories, learning, power, decision-making, ethics, culture, communication, leadership, teamwork, and motivation. Teaching methods include case studies, role play, simulation exercises, class discussions, personality and skill surveys, along with lectures and readings based on current research.

APS420H1.name: Technology, Engineering and Global Development
APS420H1.description: This course examines the role of technology and engineering in global development. It includes lectures, readings, case studies, and analyses of key technologies in fields such as energy, information and communications, water, and healthcare. Topics cover a history and theories of international development and foreign aid, major governmental and non-governmental organizations, alternative models like social entrepreneurship and microfinance, social venture capital and philanthropy, financial markets, environmental and sustainable development issues, and technology diffusion and appropriate technologies.

APS500H1.name: Negotiations in an Engineering Context
APS500H1.description: This course focuses on the instruction of negotiation concepts, theories, research, and primarily the practice of negotiation skills tailored for engineers. It encompasses various negotiation scenarios that engineers may encounter throughout their careers, ranging from simple single-issue, single-party negotiations to complex multi-party, multi-issue scenarios.

APS502H1.name: Financial Engineering
APS502H1.description: This course focuses on capital budgeting, financial optimization, and project evaluation models, including their solution techniques. It delves into linear, non-linear, and integer programming models and their solutions. The course provides engineering students with a background in modern capital budgeting and financial techniques applicable in practical engineering and commercial settings.

APS510H1.name: Innovative Technologies and Organizations in Global Energy Systems
APS510H1.description: This course explores a wide array of global energy systems, including electricity generation and use, transportation, and infrastructure. It focuses on two main trends: the global deployment of technologies and engineering systems, and innovative organizations, often driven by for-profit and social entrepreneurship, as well as entrepreneurial finance techniques. The course examines these innovations in developed economies, rapidly developing economies like India and China, and the developing world, using a mix of industry examples and in-depth case studies. These are analyzed from engineering, business, and environmental sustainability perspectives.

APS511H1.name: Inventions and Patents for Engineers
APS511H1.description: This course equips engineers and scientists with the knowledge and skills necessary for preparing a patent application for an invention. It guides students through the process of developing an invention from conception to the point where a patent application can be filed. The course covers writing an invention disclosure, preparing the background section, a brief listing of figures, a detailed description of the invention, as well as crafting independent and dependent claims, an abstract, and artwork. Additionally, it introduces the use of patent search engines.

APS521H1.name: Building Organizations: An Engineer's Business Toolkit
APS521H1.description: This course provides engineers with practical tools and strategies for designing, starting, growing, managing, changing, fixing, and evolving successful organizations in the engineering industry. It focuses on developing a model for analyzing an organization and applying it in clear, simple steps. The curriculum is tailored for engineers aiming to lead organizations, commercialize product ideas, or manage change in existing institutions.

CHE488H1.name: Entrepreneurship and Business for Engineers
CHE488H1.description: This course offers a comprehensive introduction to small business formation, management, and wealth creation. Topics include: the nature of the Entrepreneur and the Canadian business environment; idea generation and Business Plan construction; business acquisition, franchising, family business succession; market research and data sources; marketing strategies including promotion, pricing, advertising, electronic channels, and costing; sales process and management, distribution channels, global marketing; accounting, finance, funding sources, financial controls; management styles, recruitment, legal employment issues, human resources; business formation, taxation, intellectual property protection; e-Business participation; managing business operations, supplier relations, ethical practices; and business exit strategies. Students develop a full Business Plan, with top submissions entering a competition. The course features real-world examples, guest entrepreneur presentations, and class visits.

ECO101H1.name: Principles of Microeconomics
ECO101H1.description: An introduction to economic analysis and its applications, this course covers price determination, market structure, and decision-making by individuals and firms, along with public policy. It involves extensive use of graphical and quantitative analysis.

ECO102H1.name: Principles of Macroeconomics
ECO102H1.description: This course offers an introduction to economic analysis and its applications from a macroeconomic perspective, covering topics such as international trade and finance, the role of money and the banking system, and monetary and fiscal policy. Graphical and quantitative analysis are extensively used.

FOR308H1.name: Discovering Wood and its Role in Societal Development
FOR308H1.description: This course delves into the historical significance of trees and wood in human development, exploring their use for shelter, heat, entertainment, weaponry, sports, furnishings, communication, food, and medicine. It examines the co-evolution of nature and culture, focusing on the social and economic impacts of forests and their exploitation in societal development from biblical times to the present. The cultural history of wood and its products, along with their influence on evolving societies, is a key focus. The course highlights how wood's versatility has been harnessed across different eras, examining its unique properties and role in sustainable societies.

GGR251H1.name: Geography of Innovation
GGR251H1.description: This course examines the development and sustainability of new technologies and industries, exploring the dynamics of leading sectors like electronics, automobiles, and biotechnology. It places these sectors in their geographical and historical contexts, with a critical analysis of regions renowned for innovation such as Silicon Valley. The course also investigates the significant contributions of universities and finance in fostering innovation and entrepreneurship.

GGR252H1.name: Marketing Geography
GGR252H1.description: This course explores the importance of geography in the success of both public and private sector organizations, primarily through retail examples. It addresses contemporary location problems, analyses the geographies of demand and supply, and applies trade area and site selection techniques. The course also highlights the relevance of the planning context and the utility of geovisualization techniques such as GIS in marketing geography.

HPS283H1.name: The Engineer in History
HPS283H1.description: This course focuses on the history of engineers, emphasizing their roles as workers, members of professional groups, and managers, rather than the specifics of engineering itself. It aims to provide an understanding of engineers' heritage and their contributions to the economy and society. The course will explore the evolution of the engineering profession, examining the broader context of engineers' work throughout history.

MIE354H1.name: Business Process Engineering
MIE354H1.description: This course emphasizes understanding and integrating information systems to support enterprise objectives. It focuses on Business Process Management techniques and tools to align an organization's business and IT perspectives. Topics include the design, operation, and support of information systems, covering legacy systems, client/server architecture, the Internet, World Wide Web, and web-service-based service-oriented architecture. Students will develop business processes in the lab, utilizing BPEL, a standard for web-service-based business processes.

MIE540H1.name: Product Design
MIE540H1.description: This course offers a comprehensive perspective on product design, starting from market need identification to concept evolution and optimization. It integrates business and engineering concepts through examples, case studies, and a final project. Business aspects include customer need identification, project management, and product design economics. Engineering tools cover product specifications, concept generation and selection, functional decomposition, orthogonal arrays, factorials, noise analysis, tolerance, and robust technology for optimization. The course emphasizes robust and tunable technology for product optimization.

PHL295H1.name: Business Ethics
PHL295H1.description: This course delves into philosophical issues in ethics, social theory, and theories of human nature as they relate to the contemporary conduct of business. Topics include the moral responsibilities of business, the feasibility of calculating social costs and benefits, the influence of business on human nature and vice versa, and the role of political ideas and institutions such as democracy within the business context.

TEP234H1.name: Entrepreneurship and Small Business
TEP234H1.description: Part 1 of the 2 Part Entrepreneurship Program, this course explores the strategic use of technology in business for wealth creation. It emphasizes the advantages of entrepreneurship, covering who entrepreneurs are, the Canadian business environment, acquisitions, business types, franchising, human resources, leadership, and business law. The course includes guest speakers, assignments, and a session project. It prepares students for the follow-up course TEP432 and awards a certificate upon completion of both courses. The focus is on real-life issues, not theoretical concepts, and it includes diverse topics relevant to entrepreneurs.

TEP343H1.name: Engineering Leadership
TEP343H1.description: Focusing on the practical aspects of engineering leadership, this course is based on the idea that technology must be translated through people to become a reality. It covers the meaning, processes, and tools of leading, including creating visions and motivating others. The course uses learning frameworks and personal working style inventories to help students understand human nature and learning logic. It aims to develop competence in self-leadership, team leadership, and organizational leadership. Topics include transformational change, organizational culture, high-performance work systems, and self-leadership. The course involves lectures, readings, discussions, and a team project involving an interview with an engineering CEO or a senior community leader. Students are also required to submit written reflections on the course content and their personal experiences.

TEP432H1.name: Entrepreneurship and Business Management
TEP432H1.description: Part 2 of the Entrepreneurship Program, this course is suited for those planning a career in a small business or a family enterprise, though the skills are valuable in any business context. Focusing on practical experience, the course avoids theoretical work, instead emphasizing real-life business opportunities and challenges. Topics include marketing and sales, legal issues, business financing, human resources, and business planning. Students will gain practical knowledge and skills necessary for entrepreneurship, including creating a full Business Plan as a session project. Guest speakers from the business community will contribute to class discussions, offering a real-world perspective on entrepreneurship.

TEP442H1.name: Cognitive and Psychological Foundations of Effective Leadership
TEP442H1.description: This course delves into the cognitive and psychological aspects underpinning effective leadership. It covers current theories in leadership, including neurophysiological and psychodynamic approaches. Key skills such as mental modeling, decision-making, teamwork, and self-evaluation are emphasized. Designed for engineering students, the course aims to impart practical skills to enhance leadership capabilities throughout their careers.

TEP444H1.name: Positive Psychology for Engineers
TEP444H1.description: This course explores the concept of happiness from various perspectives including philosophy, anthropology, psychology, sociology, neurobiology, film, art, and literature, and then applies engineering principles to this understanding. Concepts such as 'balance', 'flow', 'amplitude', and 'dynamic equilibrium' are used to examine happiness through an engineering lens. The course aims to provide both academic challenge, by analyzing texts from diverse disciplines, and personal growth, by exploring happiness in relation to personal development and success as an engineer.

TEP445H1.name: The Power of Story: Discovering Your Leadership Narrative
TEP445H1.description: This course introduces relational, authentic, and transformational leadership theories through the lens of narrative and storytelling. Students will practice storytelling techniques, learn the mechanics of stories, enhance public speaking skills, reflect on personal history and identity, and develop critical thinking about prevalent narratives, especially in relation to engineering problems and ethics. The course is experiential, emphasizing reading, discussion, storytelling practice, and reflection.

TEP448H1.name: System Mapping
TEP448H1.description: This course extends the concept of systems thinking beyond technical aspects to include social and environmental considerations. System mapping, a tool used in public health and environmental policy, is taught to describe complex problems involving multiple stakeholders. Students will apply system mapping techniques to problems with technical, social, and environmental dimensions, exploring relevant fields like public policy, sociology, and law. The course focuses on problem definition through a team project developing a system map for a complex issue. The goal is to identify potential solutions, although the emphasis is on understanding the problem.

CSC263H1.name: Data Structures and Analysis
CSC263H1.description: This course delves into algorithm analysis, including worst-case, average-case, and amortized complexity, and introduces expected worst-case complexity through examples like randomized quicksort and selection. It covers standard abstract data types such as graphs, dictionaries, priority queues, and disjoint sets, and explores a variety of data structures for implementing these types, including balanced search trees, hashing, heaps, and disjoint forests. The course emphasizes the design, comparison, and implementation of data structures and introduces lower bounds.
tags: Design and Comparison of Data Structures

MIE245H1.name: Data Structures and Algorithms
MIE245H1.description: This course offers an introduction to the principles of algorithm design, analysis, and implementation. It covers basic data structures such as lists, sets, maps, stacks, and queues. Topics also include graphs and graph search, decision algorithms (including greedy methods and approximation algorithms), sorting techniques, divide-and-conquer strategies, recursive algorithms, trees, heaps, priority queues, hashing, and hash tables. Additionally, the course examines algorithmic analysis, focusing on big-O complexity, and applies these concepts to numerical methods including matrix inversion, decomposition, and solving linear systems of equations.

MIE369H1.name: Introduction to Artificial Intelligence
MIE369H1.description: An introduction to the field of Artificial Intelligence, covering fundamental topics like search, constraint satisfaction, knowledge representation through propositional and first-order logic, representing uncertainty with Bayesian networks, and decision making under uncertainty. The course also explores reinforcement learning, the distinctions between weak and strong AI, the engineering aspects of AI, and ethical and safety considerations in AI.

ROB311H1.name: Artificial Intelligence
ROB311H1.description: This course provides an introduction to artificial intelligence from a mathematical perspective, tracing its historical development and discussing key results. Topics include the philosophy of AI, search methods in problem solving, knowledge representation and reasoning, logic, planning, and various learning paradigms. Special focus is given to ethical considerations in AI, embodied AI, and the pursuit of artificial general intelligence.

CSC311H1.name: Introduction to Machine Learning
CSC311H1.description: An introduction to machine learning, covering automated learning of relationships based on empirical data. Topics include classification and regression using nearest neighbour methods, decision trees, linear models, neural networks, and clustering algorithms. The course addresses problems of overfitting and accuracy assessment, along with the basics of reinforcement learning.

MIE424H1.name: Optimization in Machine Learning
MIE424H1.description: This course aims to deepen understanding and enhance flexibility in using standard machine learning methods by developing machine learning from an optimization perspective. It enables students to apply machine learning methods to finance and marketing problems, including stock return forecasting, credit risk scoring, portfolio management, fraud detection, and customer segmentation.

ROB313H1.name: Introduction to Learning from Data
ROB313H1.description: This course offers an introduction to machine learning, emphasizing its importance in designing intelligent systems and deriving insights from data in computational science and engineering. It covers both the theoretical foundations and computational algorithms for unsupervised and supervised learning, including clustering, k-means, principal component analysis, linear regression and classification, generalized linear models, the bias-variance tradeoff, regularization, maximum likelihood estimation, kernel methods, support vector machines, generalization theory, feedforward neural networks, stochastic gradient descent, ensemble learning, and model selection and validation.

CHE408H1.name: Data Analytics for Prediction, Control, and Optimization of Chemical Processes
CHE408H1.description: An industry-oriented approach to data analytics for chemical process engineers, covering data acquisition, exploratory data analysis, sensitivity analysis, data-based modeling for prediction, monitoring, control, and optimization of chemical processes.

CHE507H1.name: Data-based Modelling for Prediction and Control
CHE507H1.description: Students will learn to build mathematical models of dynamic systems for prediction and control, focusing on a system identification approach using observations to build models. The course covers continuous and discrete time representations, deterministic and stochastic models, and uses interactive learning with computer-based tools in Matlab, including the System Identification Toolbox and the Model Predictive Control Toolbox.

CME538H1.name: Introduction to Data Science for Civil and Mineral Engineers
CME538H1.description: Acting as a bridge between foundational courses and upper-level machine learning, computer science, and statistics courses, this course explores key Data Science areas including question formulation, data collection and cleaning, visualization, and applied machine learning. With a strong emphasis on coding, it aims to establish a robust foundation in programming. Covering a range of topics from visualization to machine learning, the course is designed to provide an appreciation for the interplay between these areas. It is introductory, setting the stage for further study in advanced courses across ECE, MIE, and CS disciplines.

CSC401H1.name: Natural Language Computing
CSC401H1.description: An introduction to natural language processing and speech techniques for applications such as information retrieval, speech recognition and synthesis, machine translation, summarization, and dialogue. Topics include N-grams, corpus analysis, neural methods, and information theory. The course involves practical programming with Python and other software, providing hands-on experience in natural language computing.

CSC412H1.name: Probabilistic Learning and Reasoning
CSC412H1.description: An introduction to the use of probability for representing and reasoning with uncertain knowledge. The course covers qualitative and quantitative specification of probability distributions using probabilistic graphical models, algorithms for inference and reasoning, and statistical methods for learning probability models from data. Applications in artificial intelligence and machine learning are discussed, illustrating the practical use of these models.

CSC413H1.name: Neural Networks and Deep Learning
CSC413H1.description: An introduction to the field of neural networks and deep learning, including foundational concepts like backpropagation and automatic differentiation. The course covers key architectures such as convolutional networks and recurrent neural networks, and discusses methods for improving optimization and generalization. It also explores the application of neural networks in unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

CSC420H1.name: Introduction to Image Understanding
CSC420H1.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of computer vision, including the extraction of image features at multiple scales, robust model parameter estimation, multiview geometry, reconstruction, image motion estimation and tracking, and object recognition. The course may also cover topics in scene understanding as time permits.

CSC485H1.name: Computational Linguistics
CSC485H1.description: An exploration of computational linguistics and the processing of language by computer. Topics covered include context-free grammars; chart parsing, statistical parsing; semantics and semantic interpretation; ambiguity resolution techniques; and reference resolution, with an emphasis on statistical learning methods for lexical, syntactic, and semantic knowledge acquisition.

CSC486H1.name: Knowledge Representation and Reasoning
CSC486H1.description: The course focuses on representing knowledge symbolically for automated reasoning. Topics may include first-order logic, entailment, resolution method, Horn clauses, procedural representations, production systems, description logics, inheritance networks, defaults and probabilities, tractable reasoning, abductive explanation, representation of action, and planning. It aims to provide students with an understanding of various methods and challenges in knowledge representation and reasoning.

HPS340H1.name: The Limits of Machine Intelligence
Prerequisites: Completion of 4.0 credits including 0.5 credit in any HPS/ PHL/ COG course
HPS340H1.description: This course examines the philosophical and scientific challenges surrounding the definitions and measurements of intelligence within AI research, particularly in the context of deep learning neural networks (DNNs). It questions the capabilities of DNNs, the Turing test's relevance, the pursuit of general intelligence, and the comparison between artificial and biological systems. Drawing from the history and philosophy of science, it explores debates around the limits of AI, offering insights from rationalist and empiricist perspectives to contemporary discussions on AI's nature and potential.

HPS345H1.name: Quantifying the World: the Debates on the Ethical and Epistemic Implications of AI and Automation
HPS345H1.description: This course explores the significant impact of automation, computing, and information technology on society, including the almost cult-like trust in mechanization and its transformations at both material and epistemological levels. It examines the ethical and epistemological debates surrounding AI and automation across various sectors, including military, cybersecurity, medical diagnostics, epidemiology, automotive industry, and personal use. The course analyzes a range of media and tools, such as data visualization, mapping, AI, and robotics, within the context of popular and controversial examples.

HPS346H1.name: Modifying and Optimizing Life: on the Peculiar Alliance between AI, Biology, and Engineering
HPS346H1.description: Exploring the historical entanglements between biology and information technology, this course examines the convergence of computer science, biology, and engineering. It delves into the commonalities and associations between AI, synthetic biology, and biotechnology, and the ethical and societal debates these associations evoke. Topics include geoengineering, bioremediation, GMOs, robotic insects, the application of machine learning in synthetic biology, precision and personalized medicine, immunotherapy, and the ethics of CRISPR technology. The course aims to unpack the complex interactions at the intersection of these fields.

MIE368H1.name: Analytics in Action
MIE368H1.description: Focusing on the practical impact of analytics, this course presents real-world examples and case studies to illustrate the application of analytics in various domains. It emphasizes decision analytics, combining data and models to enhance decision-making. Covered methods include linear and logistic regression, classification and regression trees, clustering, as well as linear and integer optimization. Applications span across healthcare, business, sports, manufacturing, finance, transportation, and the public sector, showcasing analytics in action.

MIE451H1.name: Decision Support Systems
MIE451H1.description: This course aims to provide an understanding of the significance of decision support systems within organizations, detailing their components and the theoretical and practical techniques used in their construction. It emphasizes information analysis for organizational decision-making, covering information retrieval, descriptive and predictive modeling with machine learning and data mining, recommendation systems, and the effective visualization and communication of analytical results.

MIE457H1.name: Knowledge Modelling and Management
MIE457H1.description: The course delves into the modelling and management of knowledge within and across organizations, focusing on understanding knowledge types and their semantic representation. It covers emerging web-based knowledge representations like schemas and RDF. On the management side, it addresses the acquisition, indexing, distribution, and evolution of knowledge, incorporating the use of emerging Knowledge Management System software in laboratory work.

MIE509H1.name: AI for Social Good
MIE509H1.description: This course addresses the design and development of AI systems aimed at beneficial social impacts, focusing on the application of AI methods to societal problems rather than the mechanics of AI algorithms. Topics include safeguarding human interests such as fairness and privacy in AI applications, effective human-AI partnership, evaluation of AI-assisted interventions, and practical considerations in AI method selection for societal problem-solving. Case studies illustrating the challenges and opportunities in implementing AI for social good will be explored. Class activities encompass lectures, seminars, labs, and assignments.

MIE524H1.name: Data Mining
MIE524H1.description: An introduction to data mining and machine learning algorithms for handling very large datasets, with a focus on scalability through MapReduce, Spark, and modern machine learning frameworks. Topics include algorithms for high-dimensional data, large-scale graph data analysis, infinite data stream handling, and applications of scalable data mining and machine learning algorithms.

MIE562H1.name: Scheduling
MIE562H1.description: A practical approach to understanding scheduling problems and solution techniques, with a focus on real-world applications. The course discusses mathematical definitions of scheduling, job shop scheduling, timetabling, project scheduling, and various solution methods such as constraint programming, local search, heuristics, and dispatch rules. It also explores the information engineering aspects of developing scheduling systems to address real-world challenges.

MIE566H1.name: Decision Making Under Uncertainty
MIE566H1.description: This course covers methods of analysis for decision making in uncertain environments and against adversaries. Topics include subjective probability (discrete and continuous), utility functions, decision trees, influence diagrams, Bayesian networks, multi-attribute utility functions, and both static and dynamic games with complete and incomplete information, including Bayesian games. The course also integrates the use of supporting software for decision analysis.

MIE567H1.name: Dynamic & Distributed Decision Making
MIE567H1.description: This course introduces fundamental concepts and mathematical frameworks for sequential decision making under uncertainty. It covers utility theory, uncertainty modeling, the theory of games, dynamic programming, and multi-agent systems. The course discusses the application of decision theories in designing algorithms and processes for real-world cases, providing students with the tools to approach dynamic and distributed decision-making challenges scientifically.

MSE403H1.name: Data Sciences and Analytics for Materials Engineers
MSE403H1.description: This course introduces the fundamentals of data sciences, materials informatics, and data analytics within the context of materials science and engineering, focusing on applications for accelerated materials development. It covers machine learning techniques including supervised and unsupervised learning, linear and nonlinear regression, decision trees, and artificial neural networks. Students will learn to program these algorithms in Python and apply them to case studies related to structure-property relations in materials science, alloy design, additive manufacturing, and green energy technologies.

MSE465H1.name: Application of Artificial Intelligence in Materials Design
Recommended Preparation: Strong background in math, programming, AI, and machine learning
MSE465H1.description: This course offers an insight into the use of machine learning for materials design, covering domains such as physical metallurgy, catalysis, and mechanics of materials. It starts with a review of statistical, numerical methods, and programming in R and Python, before delving into essential machine learning techniques relevant to materials science like regression analysis, decision trees, artificial neural networks, deep learning, and both supervised and unsupervised learning. Students gain practical experience through hands-on case studies in alloy design, additive manufacturing, and catalyst design, culminating in a term project on a materials science problem of their choice. The course welcomes students from various disciplines, including Chemical Engineering, Mechanical and Industrial Engineering, Chemistry, and beyond.

ROB501H1.name: Computer Vision for Robotics
ROB501H1.description: This course introduces computer vision with a focus on robotics. Topics include image formation geometry, image processing, camera models, calibration methods, feature detection, matching, stereo vision, structure from motion, 3D reconstruction, and the role of machine learning and deep neural networks in tasks like segmentation, object detection, and tracking. It features case studies of successful robotic vision systems, blending theory with practical applications in robotic vision.

CHE332H1.name: Reaction Kinetics
CHE332H1.description: This course covers the rates of chemical processes, including the measurement of reaction rates, determination of reaction orders and activation energies, and the exploration of theories of reaction rates. It delves into reaction mechanisms and networks, the development of rate laws for simple and complex kinetic schemes, the approach to equilibrium, and both homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysis. The course also examines the performance of simple chemical reactor types, providing students with a comprehensive understanding of reaction kinetics.

ECE557H1.name: Linear Control Theory
ECE557H1.description: This course adopts a state-space approach to linear system theory, covering the mathematical foundations in linear algebra, state-space equations versus transfer functions, solutions to linear ODEs, state transition matrix, Jordan form, controllability, eigenvalue assignment through state feedback, observability, observer design, the separation principle, Kalman filters, tracking, regulator problems, and linear quadratic optimal control. The stability of systems is also discussed. Laboratories are designed to complement the theoretical content with practical state space control design methodology.

MAT336H1.name: Elements of Analysis
MAT336H1.description: Provides a foundational understanding of analysis and rigorous calculus for students planning to engage in subsequent courses where these mathematical concepts are crucial. The course includes topics on the topology of Rn, implicit and inverse function theorems, and a rigorous integration theory, aimed at students who have previously taken courses with limited exposure to proofs.

MAT389H1.name: Complex Analysis
MAT389H1.description: This course delves into complex analysis, covering analytic functions, the Cauchy-Riemann equations, contour integration, Cauchy's theorem, Taylor and Laurent series, singularities, residue calculus, conformal mapping, and harmonic functions. It also addresses the Dirichlet and Neumann problems, Poisson integral formulas, and studies linear differential equations in the complex plane, including Bessel and Legendre functions.

STA302H1.name: Methods of Data Analysis I
STA302H1.description: Introduction to data analysis focusing on regression, covering initial data examination, correlation, simple and multiple regression models using least squares. Topics include inference for regression parameters, confidence and prediction intervals, diagnostics, remedial measures, interactions, dummy variables, variable selection, and least squares estimation for non-linear regression.

STA410H1.name: Statistical Computation
STA410H1.description: This course focuses on programming within an interactive statistical environment, emphasizing the generation of random variates and the evaluation of statistical methods through simulation. It covers algorithms for linear models, maximum likelihood estimation, Bayesian inference, and includes statistical algorithms like the Kalman filter and the EM algorithm. A significant component of the course is dedicated to the graphical display of data, providing a comprehensive skill set for statistical computation and analysis.

PMU299Y.name: Applied Performance
PMU299Y.description: 2018-2019 Pilot Program for classical music performance, including solo instrumental applied (classical) and chamber ensemble (classical). Limited to eight pianists, four string players, and two chamber groups, requiring auditions for entrance. Focuses on individual and small group instruction in classical music or jazz, supervised by qualified Doctor of Musical Arts students and faculty members.

TMU130H1.name: Music Theory I
TMU130H1.description: Covers diatonic harmony, including the principles of voice leading and harmonic progression, along with an introduction to musical form.

TMU111H1.name: Introduction to Computer Applications in Music
TMU111H1.description: A survey of digital music technology, including engraving, MIDI, sound and digital audio, sequencing, synthesis, recording and sampling, signal processing, and mixing and mastering. The course provides an overview of the hardware and software ecosystem supporting electronic music production, with an emphasis on listening and analyzing a broad spectrum of electronic music. Coursework is practical and focuses on the creative and proficient use of a digital audio workstation, culminating in a final project.

TMU319H1.name: Electro-acoustic Music I
TMU319H1.description: A survey of techniques employed in the composition of electroacoustic music, including class instruction and mandatory studio time.

TMU320H1.name: Electro-acoustic Music II
