TMU320H1.description: Covers advanced topics in electroacoustic music, including software synthesis, digital signal processing, and algorithmic composition. Includes two hours of class instruction and a minimum of two hours of studio time each week. Enrollment is limited.

TMU313H1.name: Introduction to Music Recording
TMU313H1.description: Recording music has become an essential part of a musician‚Äôs career, with technological advancements making music more accessible worldwide. This course offers both lectures and hands-on tutorials to introduce students to the basic theory and practical skills required for music recording.

TMU330H1.name: Live Coding: Digital Audio in Real Time
TMU330H1.description: Live coding is an emergent creative practice at the intersection of composition, improvisation, performance, and computer programming. Using the highly approachable ChucK programming language, students will learn to create and manipulate digital audio in real time, culminating in a final project and performance. Previous computer programming experience is not required.

MusicRelatedThesisOrCapstone.name: Music Related Thesis or Capstone
MusicRelatedThesisOrCapstone.description: This course allows students to engage in a significant project related to music, which could be a thesis or capstone project. Designed to integrate and apply comprehensive knowledge gained throughout the program, the project emphasizes research, creativity, and application in areas such as music technology, performance, composition, or music theory. Approval from the faculty is required to ensure that the proposed project meets academic standards and contributes meaningfully to the student's educational objectives.

HMU111H1.name: Introduction to Music and Society
exclusions: Does not count as an HMU elective
HMU111H1.description: An examination of musical thought and practice in non-Western and Western traditions, exploring the role and impact of music in various societies throughout history. This course offers insights into the diversity of musical expressions and their societal contexts, aiming to deepen the understanding of music's place in human culture.

TMU131H1.name: Music Theory II
TMU131H1.description: Explores chromatic harmony, covering topics such as modulation, mixture, Neapolitan, and augmented sixths, building upon the foundational knowledge acquired in Music Theory I.

BME412H1.name: Introduction to Biomolecular Engineering
BME412H1.description: This course delves into the mechanics and dynamics at the heart of molecular biology, focusing on the design of novel proteins, DNA, and RNA. It lays a foundational understanding of biomolecular structure, function, thermodynamics, and kinetics. The curriculum spans a variety of computational and experimental methods, including atomistic simulations, bioinformatics, machine learning, high-throughput screening, and gene editing techniques, providing a comprehensive introduction to the field of biomolecular engineering.

CHE450H1.name: Bioprocess Technology and Design
CHE450H1.description: This course is focused on applying engineering principles to bioprocess engineering, expanding on the foundations laid in CHE353 and CHE354. It covers the energetics and stoichiometry of cell growth, kinetics of cell and enzyme reactions, metabolic modeling, design of bioreactors, and processes for bioseparation. Students will engage in practical learning through two laboratory exercises that include the setup and operation of bioreactors, providing a comprehensive understanding of bioprocess technology and design.

CHE475H1.name: Biocomposites: Mechanics and Bioinspiration
CHE475H1.description: Provides an overview of natural and biological materials, biomaterials for biomedical applications, and eco-composites from renewable resources. Covers linear elasticity, viscoelasticity, dynamic mechanical response, composite reinforcement, and time-temperature correspondence. Discusses biomechanics, biomimetic design, and materials' ecological impact. Includes processing methods and characterization techniques, emphasizing structure-property relationships across materials from wood and bone to synthetic composites.

MSE343H1.name: Biomaterials
MSE343H1.description: This course offers an in-depth overview of biomaterials, focusing on the integration of fundamental biological concepts with materials design and selection, specifically tailored for CHE students. It addresses key applications in biomedical devices, exploring the biological responses they elicit. The concept of biocompatibility is thoroughly examined, alongside crucial biological principles necessary for biomaterial selection and implant design. The course also delves into the structure-property relationships prevalent in both biological materials and those inspired by biological systems.

MSE440H1.name: Emerging Applications in Biomaterials
MSE440H1.description: This course explores the current landscape of biomaterials utilized in the creation of surgical implants and dental restorations, including metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites. It examines the selection and processing of these materials to meet biocompatibility and functional needs in various applications. A significant focus is placed on the materials used in scaffolds for tissue engineering and the strategies for the repair, regeneration, and augmentation of degenerated or traumatized tissues. Key considerations include biocompatibility issues and the functionality required for specific applications.

BME350H1.name: Biomedical Systems Engineering I: Organ Systems
BME350H1.description: This course serves as an introduction to human anatomy and physiology, focusing particularly on the nervous, cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, and endocrine systems. It delves into the structures and mechanisms crucial for the proper functioning of these complex systems, both in health and disease. Emphasis is placed on the integration of organ systems and the vital structure-function relationship. Additionally, the course explores how biomedical engineering technologies contribute to maintaining homeostasis.

BME395H1.name: Biomedical Systems Engineering II: Cells and Tissues
BME395H1.description: An introductory course on tissue engineering, drawing upon developmental biology concepts. It covers the study of animal development at cellular and molecular levels, touching upon topics such as developmental patterning, differential gene expression, morphogenesis, stem cells, and the processes of repair and regeneration.

MIE439H1.name: Cellular and Tissue Biomechanics
MIE439H1.description: This course provides an introduction to the application of mechanical engineering principles, focusing on solid mechanics and rheology, to living systems. It covers cellular mechanics and the mechanics of hard and soft tissues, incorporating both experimental approaches and analytical modelling. The course highlights the applications of these principles to biomimetic and biomechanical design, culminating in a significant, integrative group project.

MIE458H1.name: Biofluid Mechanics
MIE458H1.description: This course equips students with the knowledge to apply fundamental fluid mechanics principles to biological systems. It is structured into three modules, focusing initially on the human circulatory and respiratory systems. Topics include blood rheology, flow within the heart, arteries, veins, microcirculation, the heart's mechanical properties as a pump; airflow in the lungs and airways, mass transfer across system walls, the fluid mechanics of alveoli's liquid-air interface, and clinical aid mechanical systems and devices. The final module expands to various fluid problems in modern biology.

MIE520H1.name: Biotransport Phenomena
MIE520H1.description: Focuses on the application of conservation relations and momentum balances, dimensional analysis, scaling, along with mass, heat, and fluid flow transfer principles to biological systems. Topics include transport in the circulatory system, transport in porous media and tissues, transvascular transport, gas exchange between blood and tissues, and transport phenomena in organs and whole organisms.

BME330H1.name: Patents in Biology and Medical Devices
BME330H1.description: This course focuses on the application of patent logic to a variety of product cases within biology and biomedical engineering, with a continuous commercial context in case studies. Students will engage in team-based in-class problem solving, learning to apply criteria such as obviousness, inventiveness, novelty, and enablement, drawing on historical applications of these tests in technology patents. Claim construction is explored to understand protection strategies in patenting technologies. Course materials include selected readings but no textbook, targeting senior undergraduate students.

BME530H1.name: Human Whole Body Biomechanics
BME530H1.description: This course offers an introduction to the biomechanics of human body movement, covering dynamics of human motion and the neural motor system, particularly focusing on the adaptability of the motor system. Students will learn basic techniques for capturing and analyzing human motion, with an emphasis on engineering applications in the realm of rehabilitation engineering, supported by other experimental materials. Aimed at senior undergraduate and graduate students, the course bridges engineering principles with applications in human movement and rehabilitation.

MIE437H1.name: Fundamentals of Injury Biomechanics and Prevention
MIE437H1.description: This course explores the application of mechanical engineering principles to understand injury mechanisms across various body regions and develop prevention strategies. Covering tissue-level injury mechanisms, criteria for injuries to lower and upper extremities, head, neck, and trunk, it delves into prevention through safety devices and equipment design. Also, it examines skeletal injury treatment design considerations, alongside computational (finite element and statistical analysis) and experimental (mechanical testing of crash test dummies, artificial bones, PMHS, and ex-vivo specimens) research methods in injury and orthopedic biomechanics. Forensic biomechanics case studies and protective equipment design and analysis provide practical application opportunities.

CHE471H1.name: Modelling in Biological and Chemical Systems
CHE471H1.description: This course presents methodologies for modelling biological systems, emphasizing their application across various fields. It begins with a review of physical laws and proceeds to discuss balance space selection, compartmental versus distributed models, and the application of conservation laws to discrete and continuous systems, represented through algebraic and ordinary differential equations. The course explores a broad spectrum of applications, including environmental concerns, chemical and biochemical processes, and biomedical systems, providing a comprehensive overview of modelling in biological and chemical contexts.

MGY441H1.name: Bioinformatics
MGY441H1.description: An introductory course to the computational methods and internet resources vital in modern biochemistry and molecular biology. Key topics encompass sequence and genome databases, sequence alignment, homology search, molecular structure interpretation, and phylogenetic analysis. Assignments are designed to enhance hands-on skills using web-based bioinformatics tools and databases, as well as downloadable software like molecular viewers and sequence alignment editors, integrating the use of the 'R' statistics workbench and programming language. The course aims to build competence in bioinformatics applications and provides a foundation for further exploration into systems biology in courses like BCB420H1.
MGY441H1.Note: BCB420H1 extends this syllabus to computational topics of systems biology.

BCB420H1.name: Computational Systems Biology
BCB420H1.description: This course delves into the current methodologies of using computers to analyze and model biology as integrated molecular systems. It combines lectures with practical, hands-on exercises to reinforce learning. Building on the foundations laid in an introductory Bioinformatics course, it extends and complements the knowledge base into the realm of computational systems biology, offering insights into the computational techniques and tools used for systemic analysis.

CHE462H1.name: Food Engineering
CHE462H1.description: This course focuses on the quantitative application of chemical engineering principles to the large-scale production of food, covering both molecular aspects and unit operations of food processing. It delves into the chemistry and kinetics of specific food processes and the application of traditional chemical engineering unit operations (such as distillation, extraction, drying) alongside food-specific unit operations (such as extrusion, thermal processing, and refrigeration/freezing).

CHE564H1.name: Pulp and Paper Processes
CHE564H1.description: This course covers the processes involved in pulping, bleaching, and papermaking, using them as a framework to integrate and apply chemical engineering principles. Topics include chemical reactions, phase changes, and the fundamentals of heat, mass, and momentum transfer. The course examines processes across four scales: molecular, diffusional, unit operations, and mill scale. Tutorials feature student presentations on selected topics, fostering in-depth discussions.

CIV342H1.name: Water and Wastewater Treatment Processes
CIV342H1.description: This course delves into the principles behind the design and operation of water and wastewater treatment facilities. It encompasses a comprehensive overview of both traditional and advanced treatment processes, including physical, chemical, and biological unit operations, as well as sludge processing techniques. The curriculum aims to provide students with a solid understanding of the various processes involved in treating water and wastewater, preparing them for roles in environmental engineering and related fields.

CIV541H1.name: Environmental Biotechnology
CIV541H1.description: This course explores the principles of designing and operating biologically-based treatment facilities with a focus on energy efficiency and sustainability. Topics include biological unit operations for water/wastewater treatment, advanced treatment methods, sludge processing and composting, natural treatment systems, and specialized bioengineered systems for applications like groundwater remediation and biological air treatment.

MGY377H1.name: Microbiology I: Bacteria
MGY377H1.description: An in-depth exploration of bacteria, focusing on their structure, biology, adaptability, and impact on human health. The course lays the groundwork for further studies in bacterial physiology, genetics, molecular pathogenesis, immunology, and environmental microbiology.

CHE416H1.name: Chemical Engineering in Human Health
CHE416H1.description: Explores the significant contributions of chemical engineers to advancements in healthcare and sanitation over the past 70 years. The course covers both historical transformations and current emerging areas where chemical engineers are making an impact on human health. Emphasizes quantitative approaches and the application of engineering tools from transport phenomena and chemical kinetics to healthcare technologies. Includes required readings, potentially an industrial visit, and a hands-on project.

CHM456H1.name: Organic Materials Chemistry
CHM456H1.description: Covers the design, synthesis, characterization, and application of organic materials with a focus on semiconducting polymers, molecular devices, self-assembled systems, and bioconjugates. Highlights classic examples and recent literature advances.

FOR421H1.name: Green Urban Infrastructure: Sustainable City Forests
FOR421H1.description: Explores urban forestry as a critical component of green infrastructure, addressing the ecological, engineering, and planning challenges of managing city trees. Discusses the engineered and ecological services provided by urban forests, their role in mitigating climate change, urban heat island effects, and their contribution to human well-being.

FOR424H1.name: Innovation and Manufacturing of Sustainable Materials
FOR424H1.description: Delves into sustainable materials from renewable resources, emphasizing bioplastics, biofibre, nanobiofibre, biocomposites, and nanobiocomposites. Focuses on manufacturing, engineering principles, and design fundamentals for creating sustainable materials.

FOR425H1.name: Bioenergy and Biorefinery Technology
FOR425H1.description: Investigates technological advances in deriving biofuels and chemical feedstocks from biomass, focusing on the chemical properties of biomass and the conversion to fuels and chemicals. Covers solid, liquid, and gaseous fuels, and valuable chemicals for applications beyond fuel.

HMB201H1.name: Introduction to Fundamental Genetics and its Applications
HMB201H1.description: Provides a comprehensive overview of genetic therapies and technologies, including gene therapy, CRISPR gene editing, and regenerative medicine. Covers gene and genome manipulation tools, applications in biotechnology, and the ethical, legal, and social implications of modern biotechnology.

HMB265H1.name: General & Human Genetics
HMB265H1.description: An introduction to classical and modern methods of genetic analysis, covering Mendelian genetics, genetics of human populations and diseases, genomics, and the applications of genetics to human society.

HPS318H1.name: History of Medicine I
Prerequisites: First-year students must have instructor's approval
HPS318H1.description: Explores the practice, teaching, and theory of medicine from ancient Greece to the early modern period, focusing on the historical development of western medicine in relation to society, politics, and culture.

HPS319H1.name: History of Medicine II
Prerequisites: First-year students must have instructor's approval
HPS319H1.description: Examines the development of medicine from the seventeenth to the twentieth century, focusing on changes in medical institutions, the diversification of healing practices, and the role of visual and material culture.

IMM250H1.name: The Immune System and Infectious Disease
IMM250H1.description: Introduces basic concepts of immunity and the immune response to infectious diseases, the breakdown leading to auto-immunity, and the history and current state of vaccination and disease prevention.

MIE242H1.name: Foundations of Cognitive Psychology
MIE242H1.description: Covers neuroanatomy and core processes in perception, memory, executive functions, language, decision-making, and action, including the impact of stress, emotions, and reward processing on cognitive functions. Explores case studies in various cognitive disorders.

MIE343H1.name: Industrial Ergonomics and the Workplace
MIE343H1.description: Explores anatomical and physiological factors underlying workplace design, including biomechanical considerations, circadian rhythms, and environmental factors like heat, light, and sound.

MIE523H1.name: Engineering Psychology and Human Performance
MIE523H1.description: Examines the relationship between behavioral science and human-machine system design, including human limitations and the design of technology to supplement human capabilities.

MIE561H1.name: Healthcare Systems
MIE561H1.description: A capstone course focusing on the application of Industrial Engineering tools to real-world problems in healthcare, emphasizing problem-solving in complex, unstructured environments.

PCL201H1.name: Introduction to Pharmacology and Pharmacokinetic Principles
PCL201H1.description: Introduces pharmacology and pharmacokinetics, covering drug absorption, distribution, metabolism, and elimination, alongside variability in drug response and adverse reactions.

PCL302H1.name: Pharmacodynamic Principles
PCL302H1.description: Covers the biological actions of drugs on membranes, enzymes, receptors, and neural and hormonal systems, including drug transmission and modulation.

PHL281H1.name: Bioethics
PHL281H1.description: An introduction to ethical and legal issues in medical practice and research, including health policy, patient rights, and contemporary issues such as euthanasia and reproductive technologies.

PSL300H1.name: Human Physiology I
PSL300H1.description: Covers neurophysiology, endocrinology, and reproductive physiology principles, tailored for life sciences students focusing on body systems' functions.
